docs.lead_paragraph: For all the complexities of the contract that the transit workers rejected the mathematics of the vote seemed to boil down to one simple number: age.

headline.main: Which Side Are You On? In Transit Voting, It Came Down to 'How Old Are You?'

headline.sub: Unexpected Rejection;  Next Step Is Unclear;

docs.snippet: The rejection represents a stunning defeat for the union's president and opens a potential Pandora's box of complications.

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN and STEVEN GREENHOUSE

docs.lead_paragraph: About 150 African-American ministers and gay activists from around the country gathered here Friday to begin a two-day conference to combat what they assert is widespread prejudice against gay men and lesbians within black churches. Though most black Christians are liberal on pocketbook issues, they are social conservatives, speakers at the conference said. Yet getting black churches to accept gay men and lesbians has gained particular urgency over the last two years, participants noted.

headline.main: Black Churches' Attitudes Toward Gay Parishioners Spur Debate at Conference

docs.snippet: African-American ministers and gay activists at the conference say that there is prejudice against gay men and lesbians in black churches.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Yorkers had their share of unneeded stress last month when transit workers walked off the job and stranded them just before the holidays. Now that the union's rank-and-file members have voted down the proposed contract -- by just 7 votes among 22,461 cast -- the city's millions of daily riders have a right to know that their transportation won't be illegally interrupted with another work stoppage. The rejection of the agreement was a self-defeating move. Roger Toussaint, president of the transit workers' local union, had waged an energetic campaign to get ratification, but the bile and resentment toward management that led to the strike had not receded. The contract would have been a good one for workers, with pay increases averaging 3.5 percent in each of the next three years. A retirement age of 55 was preserved for all employees, including the newly hired. Dissidents in the union unreasonably took umbrage over a requirement that they pay 1.5 percent of their paychecks toward health care insurance premiums.
docs.snippet: New York's millions of daily riders have a right to know that their transportation won't be illegally interrupted with another work stoppage.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the seventh day of the new Medicare drug benefit, Stephen Starnes began hearing voices again, ominous voices, and he started to beg for the medications he had been taking for 10 years. But his pharmacy could not get approval from his Medicare drug plan, so Mr. Starnes was admitted to a hospital here for treatment of paranoid schizophrenia. Mr. Starnes, 49, lives in Dayspring Village, a former motel that is licensed by the State of Florida as an assisted living center for people with mental illness. When he gets his medications, he is stable.

headline.main: Medicare Woes Take High Toll on Mentally Ill

docs.snippet: Some patients have relapsed after mix-ups in the first weeks of the new drug benefit kept them from getting their medications.

docs.lead_paragraph: CAUTION: Reading this article may provoke self-inflicted slaps to the head and utterances of ''Why didn't I do this five years ago?'' In 1999, Farhad Aghdami, a trust lawyer in Richmond, Va., suggested to Jim and Yolonda Roberts that they put their home in a Qualified Personal Residence Trust to shelter it from looming estate taxes.

headline.main: With a Little Estate Planning, Your House Can Stay in the Family

docs.snippet: As home prices have climbed sharply, many older Americans are finding themselves living in an asset worth $1 million or more.

docs.lead_paragraph: LOVE is in the air in corporate boardrooms, or is it just the realization that it can hurt to be alone? Businesses have been pursuing mergers and acquisitions more vigorously than at any time since the tech boom of the late 1990's; $2.7 trillion worth of deals were reached worldwide last year, 38.4 percent more than in 2004, according to Thomson Financial. The research firm expects another big year, and the first couple of weeks have been marked by announcements of several deals, speculation about others and the emergence of a bidding war for Guidant between Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson.

headline.main: Mergers Rise, And Analysts Take Notice

docs.snippet: LOVE is in the air in corporate boardrooms, or is it just the realization that it can hurt to be alone?.

docs.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group, a provider of medical insurance for roughly 1 in 10 Americans, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings increased 18 percent as it enrolled more customers and bought rivals. Net income rose to $870 million, or 65 cents a share, from $739 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 15 percent, to $12 billion.
docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group reports fourth-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, to $870 million, from $739 million year earlier; revenue increased 15 percent, to $12 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cargill, the grain marketing company, said yesterday that it would set up tax-free health savings accounts for farmers who pledge to sell a portion of their grain to the company. The program, which company officials say is the first in the nation, is aimed at helping farmers who are struggling with rising health insurance costs while guaranteeing business for Cargill in an increasingly competitive grain market.

headline.main: Sell a Crop And Get Help On Health Care

docs.abstract: Cargill will establish tax-free health savings accounts for farmers who pledge to sell portion of their grain to company; program, first in US, is aimed at helping farmers who are struggling with rising health insurance costs while guaranteeing business for Cargill in increasingly competitive grain market (M)
docs.snippet: Cargill will offer tax-free health savings accounts to farmers who pledge to sell a portion of their grain to the grain marketing company.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal Agency Seeks Records From Google On Internet Searches to Fight Pornography The Justice Department has asked a federal judge to compel Google to turn over records on millions of its users' search queries as part of the government's effort to uphold an online pornography law. [Page A1.] Pioneers in Animation in Merger Discussions If the Walt Disney Company acquires Pixar Animation Studios, Steven P. Jobs, who breathed life into animated movies with hits like ''The Incredibles'' and ''Toy Story,'' could take a pivotal role in shaping the convergence of new and old media at Disney. [A1.] New Documents Raise Questions for Guidant Some Guidant executives recommended that doctors be alerted about short-circuits in its heart devices six months before the company publicly disclosed them, newly released internal documents disclose. [C1.] Big Banks Find Profit in Public Facilities Big banks on Wall Street have found a new line of business by buying concession rights on public facilities like toll roads, tunnels and airports, packaging them and selling them to the public. [C1.] Tension With Iran Raises Concern for Oil Exports Iran's pursuit of nuclear technology is raising concerns that the country might use its oil exports as a political weapon, a development that would hurt the world's thirst for energy. [C1.] Merrill Lynch Says Quarterly Profit Rose 25% Merrill Lynch reported a 25 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings on the back of robust trading, a surge in banking and strong expense controls. Merrill has been branching out globally, integrating various acquisitions and reaping the results of businesses that it had rebuilt after scaling back in recent years. [C7.] Smokers Sue Tobacco Company for Cancer Tests A group of heavy, long-term Marlboro smokers filed an unusual lawsuit against Philip Morris USA seeking to require the company to pay for medical tests to detect lung cancer in its early stages. [C3.] Pfizer Posts 3% Decline in Quarterly Profit Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, said its fourth-quarter profit fell about 3 percent as sales retreated from levels a year ago. [C4.] UnitedHealth Reports Higher Profit as Enrollment Grows The UnitedHealth Group, a provider of medical insurance for about 1 in 10 Americans, said its fourth-quarter earnings increased 18 percent as it enrolled more customers and bought rivals. [C4.] Writer Says Richard Scrushy Paid for Favorable Coverage A newspaper writer said Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, paid her to produce favorable articles and reviewed them before publication during his trial on fraud charges last year. [C3.] Grain Company to Arrange Health Accounts for Farmers Cargill said it would set up tax-free health savings accounts for farmers who pledge to sell a portion of their grain to the company. [C3.] U.S. Duties on Mexican Cement to Be Phased Out The United States and Mexico agreed to phase out American duties on Mexican cement imports, a move aimed at easing cement shortages caused by reconstruction after Hurricane Katrina and by a building boom in Asia. [C4.] Tokyo Stock Exchange Plans to Double Trade Capacity After aggressive Internet orders by individual investors contributed to a near-collapse of stock trading in Tokyo, executives of the Tokyo Stock Exchange announced plans to nearly double the system's capacity for trading and clearing stocks by year's end. [C6.] Konica Minolta to Quit Making Cameras and Film Konica Minolta Holdings said it would withdraw from the camera and color film businesses, ending one of the best-known brands in the photography world. Minolta's president, Fumio Iwai, left, said the company would concentrate on color copiers for offices, liquid-crystal display materials, medical equipment and optical devices. Mr. Iwai will also step down as president and be succeeded by Yoshikatsu Ota, now a vice president. [C6.] Stocks Turn Higher on Chip Maker's Strong Outlook Stocks turned higher after the semiconductor maker Advanced Micro Devices presented a bright first-quarter outlook and a broker upgraded oil services stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average added 25.85 points, to 10,880.71. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.11 points, to 1,285.04. The Nasdaq composite index gained 22.17 points, to 2,301.81. [C7.] Regional Bank Says Quarterly Earnings Rose 18% The Wachovia Corporation, a regional bank holding company, said that earnings grew 18 percent in the fourth quarter, propelled by growth in fees, deposits and loans. [C4.]
